info:
This example uses a blank template with
the IIFE build of the front-end client.

It does not use any front-end framework, just
pure HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

name: Reload
info:
Sends a pre-formatted msg to the front-end that
causes the page to reload itself.

name: uibuilder standard output
info:
This shows the data coming out of the
uibuilder node's Port #1 (top) which is
the standard output.

Here you will see any standard msg sent from
your front-end code.

name: uibuilder control output
info:
This shows the data coming out of the
uibuilder node's Port #2 (bottom) which is
the control output.

Here you will see any control msg either sent
by the node itself or from the front-end library.

For example the "client disconnect" and
"client connect" messages. Or the "visibility"
messages from the client.

Loop the "client connect", "cache replay" and
"cache clear" messages back to a `uib-cache`
node before the input to uibuilder in order
to control the output of the cache.

name: Low-code report building with the help of uibuilder \n Chk Description in each node & in here \n You need to add a line to the HTML so that the Markdown output works correctly, see within
info:
To get the Markdown outputs to display,
please add the following line to the html
file before the reference to uibuilder's
library:

```
<script defer src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/markdown-it@latest/dist/markdown-it.min.js">/* Allows Markdown to be used in msg._ui */</script>
```

---

This example starts with the standard IIFE 
uibuilder template. You will note, however,
that you can remove all of the body HTML
and it will still work.

This is because all of the important text,
tables and layout are created dynamically
using a standardised configuration schema.

The schema used by uibuilder is actually
quite similar, at least in concept, to that
used by pdfmaker which was the inspiration
for this example. I didn't know about pdfmaker
when I designed the config-driven aspects of
uibuilder and it is comforting to know that I
came up with a similar solution to a similar
problem.

Output to HTML is far more flexible than
output to PDF via pdfmaker though and it will
continue to grow and improve as HMTL and CSS do.

You can still output the resulting page to
PDF very easily though.

---

Full documentation for uibuilder's low-code,
configuration-driven UI creation capabilities
is available in the documentation:

https://totallyinformation.github.io/node-red-contrib-uibuilder/#/uibuilder.module?id=dynamic-data-driven-html-content-1

props.v:
[{"method":"remove","components":["#ui-test"]},{"method":"add","components":[{"type":"main","id":"ui-test","parent":"#more","components":[{"type":"h1","slot":"uibuilder Low-Code Tests: Tables"},{"type":"p","slot":"This is an example of using uibuilder's low-code, config-driven page builder. It is based on the TABLES example from pdfmake. This is partly to demonstrate that pdfmake and uibuilder use related principals for similar outcomes."},{"type":"p","slot":"In addition, it demonstrates how to create a complex HTML report layout dynamically direct from Node-RED using a standardised configuration and data-driven, low-code methodology."},{"type":"p","slot":"It would be easy to directly print this to paper or print/save to PDF."},{"type":"p","slot":"Of course, much of the output configuration could also be dynamcially created from other data rather than being specified manually as in this example. Change the input from JSON to Expression for example in order to use JSONata to include data from an input msg."},{"type":"p","slot":"The input in this example is set up so that re-sending the data, removes and re-add's the entire thing. This should not be noticable in the browser. Try changing some data and resending to see the effect."},{"type":"p","slot":"Except where mentioned in the tables themselves, the majority of the styling comes from the pre-loaded uibuilder stylesheet. info:
This example sends a bunch of TABLEs to
the front-end.

It is taken from the [pdfmake]() tables example
and adapted for uibuilder.

It demonstrates how complex reports can be created
as easily in uibuilder as in pdfmake. With the 
difference being that uibuilder outputs vanilla
HTML which can be copied/pasted into many other tools.
Or printed to PDF or a printer.

name: Quote of the Day example. (Read me)
info:
This flow gets a "quote of the day" from the Internet and passes it
to uibuilder. It caches the result so that if you reload the page,
you get the last result back. The quote is updated every 30 minutes
during the day and evening.

"Simple" refers to the front-end code. While the flow looks a little
complex, it really isn't. On the Node-RED server side: A trigger, an Internet request,
and uibuilder. On the client browser side: A well-formatted HTML blockquote, a simple
function that updates the UI and a function that listens to messages from Node-RED,
and finally some really simple CSS for formatting.

## Configuration

Update the files:

* `index.html`
* `index.js`
* `index.css`

According to the example(s) in the 3 other comment nodes in this example.

Press the button on the trigger to start the flow.

name: index.html
info:
uibuilder example: Get and view a Quote of the Day

Using the uibuilder IIFE library. No framework used.
No quote received yet.

return msg;

name: deleteRow will punch holes in table!
table recorder
info:
# simple ui-table handler
## abstract
Using ui-table with commands offer the hole flexibilty of tabulator. The table can be manipulated down to cell level.
As the ui-table node only passes the commands to tabulator and receives promises back the node does not hold the table data. If the data should be available after refresh, tab change, new connections the flow is responsible to cache the data and all the manipulations.
This node takes care of most simple data manipulation commands and holds a copy of the data in `flow.context.tabledata`

## details

### row index (id)

To identify a [row a index](http://tabulator.info/docs/4.5/data#overview) column has to be defined. This colum defaults to `id` but can be changed by specifing a **field** by using `msg.ui_control`. In this example the row index is a simple counter adding up by one if a new line is added.

### addRow command

[details @ tabulator addRow docs](http://tabulator.info/docs/4.5/update#alter-add)

You can add a row by sending the `addRow` command. You can decide if the row adds on the top or at the bottom of table.

### addOrUpdate command

[details @ tabulator addOrUpdate docs](http://tabulator.info/docs/4.5/update#alter-update)

To update data the best way is to use the `addOrUpdate` command. If the row indetified by the index is not exeisting a new row will be added automatically

### deleteRow command

[details @ tabulator deleteRow docs](http://tabulator.info/docs/4.5/update#row)

Delete one or more rows (passing an array always results in "row not found error"! I think there is an issue in tabulator)

### clearData

[details @ tabulator clearData docs](http://tabulator.info/docs/4.5/update#alter-empty)

unfortunately this command (currently) do not send a promise back! So we have to pass it directly to the table handler

name: clipboardPasteAction Callback
Copy & Paste (readme)
info:
# copy & paste

You need only one callback function I included in a separate function note for better readability (do not put this into your flow.

The change node does the preparation of the table with a `msg.ui_control` object. Because you need minimum one cell to paste into (you can`t paste into an empty table) I put in some dummy data
It is not necessary to configure the the table node only tick "send data on click" to activate the output.

CTRL-c is working too. It is set to "table" (including currently invisble cells) and no styling.

[Detailed documentation of this tabulator feature can be found here.](http://tabulator.info/docs/4.5/clipboard)

Be aware that colum `field` names must match cells of the first row of the pasted data and the is tab \t and new line \n formatted, as windows clipboard does. [see here](http://tabulator.info/docs/4.5/clipboard#paste-parser)

if (msg.errorNumber == 1 && msg.successNumber == 2)
    msg.test = "All continue on error each message : success"
else
    msg.test = "All continue on error each message : failure"

return msg

name: Check
func:
if (msg.errorNumber == 1 && msg.successNumber == 1)
    msg.test = "All stop on Error each message : success"
else
    msg.test = "All stop on Error each message : failure"

return msg

name: Check
func:
if (msg.errorNumber == 0 && msg.successNumber == 1)
    msg.test = "All continue on error last message : success"
else
    msg.test = "All continue on error last message : failure"

return msg

name: Check
func:
if (msg.errorNumber == 1 && msg.successNumber == 0)
    msg.test = "All stop on error last message : success"
else
    msg.test = "All stop on error last message : failure"

return msg

name: Send a msg
info:
Send a simply msg to the front-end.

The default front-end template code will display the msg
using HTML formatting, no coding required.

This example uses the default blank template.

It does not use any front-end framework, just
pure HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

name: uibuilder standard output
info:
This shows the data coming out of the
uibuilder node's Port #1 (top) which is
the standard output.

Here you will see any standard msg sent from
your front-end code.

name: uibuilder control output
info:
This shows the data coming out of the
uibuilder node's Port #2 (bottom) which is
the control output.

Here you will see any control msg either sent
by the node itself or from the front-end library.

For example the "client disconnect" and
"client connect" messages. Or the "visibility"
messages from the client.

Loop the "client connect", "cache replay" and
"cache clear" messages back to a `uib-cache`
node before the input to uibuilder in order
to control the output of the cache.

name: Reload
info:
Sends a pre-formatted msg to the front-end that
causes the page to reload itself.

name: Plain UL/OL List (Array)
payload: ["LI One","LI Two",["LI Three a","LI Three b"],"LI Four"]

name: Plain UL/OL List (Object)
payload: {"L1":"LI One","L2":"LI Two","L3":"LI Three a","L4":["LI Four a","LI Four b"]}

name: Plain DL List (Array)
payload: [["Entry One","Description One"],["Entry Two","Description Two a","Description Two b","Description Two c"],["Entry Three","Description Three"],["Entry Four","Description Four"]]

name: Plain DL List (List of Objects)
payload: [{"Entry 1":"Description 1"},{"Entry 2a":"Description 2a","Entry 2b":"Description 2b - this wont show. Use List not object for multiple Descriptions."},{"Entry 3":["Description 3 a","Description 3 b"]},{"Entry 4":"Description 4"}]

name: Plain DL List (Object of Objects)
payload: {"ONE":{"A":"LI One A"},"TWO":{"B":["LI Two B1","LI Two B2"]},"THREE":{"C":{"C1":"LI Three C1","C2":"LI Three C2"}}}

name: Send the UL/OL list and change the Parent to `#eltest-ul-ol *[data-row-index="3"]` \n (without the quotes) to insert the table into the list entry #3

Limitation: we have to resend everything just to update one thing. 
 Instead, consider using this to create the HTML then copy the HTML using your browser's developer tools 
 then save the HTML into the index.html file. 
 You can still update using a uib-element node with the same ID or you can use a uib-update node as appropriate.

payload: A am a new list entry

[{"id":"r1","type":"text","required":false,"label":"Text Input:","value":"Foo"},{"id":"r2","type":"color","required":false,"label":"Colour:","value":"#427798"},{"id":"r3","type":"date","required":true,"label":"Date:"},{"id":"r4","type":"range","required":false,"label":"Range (0-100):","value":"20","min":0,"max":100},{"id":"r5","type":"button","label":"Send to Node-RED","value":"Buttons can have values as well"}]

name: Zero-Code Examples. Flows for all uib-element types
index.html
info:
uibuilder Sender-node example

Using the IIFE library.

The first button sends a message back to the main uibuilder node. Attach a debug node to port #1 of that node to see it.

The second button only works if you have first sent a message via a uib-sender node. When you do, pressing the button will return a msg back to the sender node and not to the main node. 

Waiting for a message from Node-RED

Note that there are only around 5 required lines of HMTL and around 30 lines of JavaScript required to make this example work. Thanks to the uibuilderfe library along with uibuilder which do all the hard work. Only 1 line of CSS gives you a decent looking output.

name: index.js
index.css
info:
/* Load the defaults from `<userDir>/node_modules/node-red-contrib-uibuilder/front-end/src/uib-styles.css` */
@import url("./uib-styles.css");

name: Make sure that you take the content of the 3 comments below and \n put them into the appropriate files using the uibuilder file editor
As soon as you import this example, press Deploy before doing anything else. \n This will create the required folders.
If you change the uibuilder URL for this example, \n make sure you Deploy and then change the selection in the uib-sender node to match.

CLEAR

info:
If you change the uibuilder settings to fwd 
input messages, this function changes an
entry to make certain that the cached variables
are NOT REFERENCES but completely separate
clones. In other words, it makes sure that there
are no unintended consequences of using the
cache.

info:
Change the "prop" value to a CSS Selector.

The display will appear as the last child of
that selected element.

e.g. `body` or `#more`.

This example uses a minimal template with
the IIFE build of the front-end client.

It does not use any front-end framework, just
pure HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

The IIFE build should be included using a link
tag in your HTML.

This example uses a blank template with
the ESM build of the front-end client.

It does not use any front-end framework, just
pure HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

The ESM build should be included using an
`import` statement in your `index.js` file.

ESM = ECMA Script Module.

This example uses the default blank template.

It does not use any front-end framework, just
pure HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

name: Notification
info:
Overlays a message on top of your UI.

The message removes itself after a couple of seconds.

You can change the options property to change the look
of the displayed message.

This example uses a Vue v3 simple template with
the IIFE build of the front-end client.

No build step is needed to make this work,
the Vue library is included from a CDN on the
Internet.


## LIMITATIONS

Vue and similar front-end frameworks require UI
components and structure to be pre-defined 
_before_ the DOM is created. So you cannot 
dynamically insert further Vue elements easily.

You can still dynamically insert HTML elements.
But they will not be responsive Vue elements.

name: New Card
info:
Inserts a pure HTML "card" into a div called `#more`.
If that div does not exist, will add to the bottom of the HTML.

Firstly attempts to remove the div so that you only ever have 1.

An example of using uibuilder's dynamic UI configuration-driven
building capabilities without the need for any fancy nodes or
frameworks. Pure HTML. But you can still utilise the extra
features of your favourite framework too if you like!

name: Send a msg
info:
Send a simply msg to the front-end.

The default front-end template code will display the msg
using HTML formatting, no coding required.

This example uses the VueJS v2 and 
bootstrap-vue template.

You must have both `Vue@2` and `bootstrap-vue`
libraries installed to use this template.

This used to be the default in some older
versions of uibuilder before the native
HTML versions started to mature.

It still provides a simple starting point
for anyone with minimal front-end design
skills in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. That is 
because, bootstrap-vue is a comprehensive 
framework complete with pre-configured look and
feel (using Bootstrap) along with plenty of 
helper components that reduce the amount of 
HTML you have to write.

The template provides a page that looks
OK with no further configuration. Simply add
your own UI code within the 
`<b-container id="app_container">` section.

The rest of the HTML in the template shows
some basic bootstrap-vue component examples
such as forms and buttons along with cards.

* https://bootstrap-vue.org/
* https://vuejs.org/
* https://getbootstrap.com/

## LIMITATIONS

Vue and similar front-end frameworks require UI
components and structure to be pre-defined 
_before_ the DOM is created. So you cannot 
dynamically insert further Vue elements easily.

You can still dynamically insert HTML elements.
But they will not be responsive Vue elements.

name: Notification
info:
**NOTE:** This uses a bootstrap-vue _toast_ notification rather
than uibuilder's vanilla HTML overlay notification (as in the
non-Vue examples). If bootstrap-vue is not loaded, it will not
show anything.

---

Overlays a message on top of your UI.

The message removes itself after a couple of seconds.

You can change the options property to change the look
of the displayed message.

Note the use of a workaround in the index.js file that lets
this work with VueJS and bootstrap-vue.

name: HTML insert (not Vue)
info:

an HTML block element. So the result is NOT responsive to Vue.
Vue and similar front-end frameworks require UI components and
structure to be pre-defined _before_ the DOM is created. So you
cannot dynamically insert further Vue elements.

building capabilities without the need for any fancy nodes or
frameworks. Pure HTML. But you can still utilise the extra
features of your favourite framework too if you like!

name: Simple Svelte Example. Chk Description in each node. Read me too
info:
This example will work once you have set and
deployed the URL. However, if you want to make
any changes to the front-end code, Svelte 
requires you to _rebuild_ the destination
output.

## Preparing
1. Go to the server command line and navigate
to the folder containing this example instance.
2. In the instance root folder, run
`npm install`. This will install all of the
required development tools.
3. Now run `npm run dev`. This starts a live
development server and it gives you a URL.
**IGNORE** the URL it gives you, because you
are using Node-RED and uibuilder, you don't
need it . Instead, you will now find that
your web page will automatically reload 
whenever you save a change.

## Making changes
Most of the changes you will make will be to
files in the `src` folder. However, if you
need to change the global CSS or the outer
HTML template, these are in the root of the 
`dist` folder. Do not change anything in 
`dist/build` as this is overwritten by the 
Svelte build process.

## Deploying
Once you have finished making changes, kill
the dev server then run `npm run build`.

That creates the final version of the code in
the dist folder.

Remember: You are running your live pages from
the `dist` folder not the `src` folder.

---

features of your favourite framework too if you like!

info:
Change the "prop" value to a CSS Selector.

The display will appear as the last child of
that selected element.

e.g. `body` or `#more`.
